title: Emotional Regulation & Intensity
description: A cinematic exploration of how you process strong emotional waves, your reactivity patterns, and your nervous system's capacity to return to baseline.

questions.text: When an unexpected stressful feeling arises, my first instinct is to...

options.text: Pause and try to locate the source.
Distract myself immediately.
Vocalize my frustration outwardly.
Shut down entirely and withdraw.

insight_cloud.title: The Pause Response
insight_cloud.text: When we pause before reacting, we create a tiny buffer zone. According to clinical protocols like Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT), this micro-pause is a profound resilience skill, allowing your nervous system to catch its breath before engaging.

questions.text: Once a heavy emotion settles in, I often feel like...

options.text: It’s a wave that will pass.
It will take hours to clear.
It defines who I am right now.
It will last forever and I am trapped in it.

questions.text: When my emotions peak, the primary sensation I notice in my body is...

options.text: A passing tension that releases.
A tight chest or shallow breathing.
Intense heat or energy I need to burn off.
Complete numbness or feeling disconnected from my body.

insight_cloud.title: The Body Speaks First
insight_cloud.text: It is incredibly common for your body to signal distress before your mind fully registers it. Research on somatic markers shows that tight chests or sudden heat are just your body's way of intensely trying to protect you.

questions.text: In close relationships, when I feel misunderstood, my reaction often triggers...

options.text: A calm attempt to clarify.
Defensiveness that I catch later.
A swift argument or conflict.
An intense fear of abandonment driving erratic actions.

questions.text: How often do you rely on intense external stimuli to numb or manage your emotional state?

options.text: Rarely, I sit with it.
Sometimes (e.g., doomscrolling).
Often, I need a distraction to survive the feeling.
Almost always, using substances or harmful actions.

questions.clinical_context: Measures maladaptive coping mechanisms. Relying on external stimuli to numb is a common nervous system adaptation to overwhelm.
